message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient had a sudden onset of severe crushing retrosternal pain that radiated to his left arm, and elevated troponins and CK-MB. This indicates acute myocardial infarction. Since the patient died within 2 hours, the gross examination of the heart will not show any significant changes yet. It takes several hours to several days for the gross changes to appear. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) normal heart tissue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Elevated troponins and CK-MB suggest a myocardial infarction. Autopsy will show normal heart tissue as this is an acute myocardial infarction, not a chronic one where scar tissue has formed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presented symptoms suggest a Myocardial infarction (heart attack). The gross examination of the heart will show normal heart tissue as there is no information to suggest any previous damage or scarring to the heart. The other options are not relevant to the presented symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient died shortly after presenting with symptoms of a heart attack, and an autopsy was performed. The gross examination of the heart will show normal heart tissue as there was no time for the heart tissue to undergo any changes or healing processes that would be visible upon gross examination. The other options describe changes that would occur over time after a heart attack has occurred.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The autopsy findings for a patient who died of a myocardial infarction may include a pale zone of infarction and softening in the area. The heart tissue will not be normal, but it will not show the other options mentioned. Red granulation tissue can be seen in healing myocardial infarctions, white, patchy, non-contractile scar can be seen in chronic infarctions, and pallor of the infarcted tissue can be seen in the acute stage of the infarction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and elevated troponins and CK-MB levels indicate a myocardial infarction. However, the autopsy will not show any gross changes immediately after death. Microscopic changes may be seen later, but the answer choices only mention gross changes. Therefore, the correct answer is (B), normal heart tissue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a heart attack and the elevated troponins and CK-MB support this. The autopsy would likely show normal heart tissue as the patient died quickly after the onset of symptoms and there may not have been enough time for the heart tissue to change. Option (A) refers to healing tissue, while option (C) refers to old scar tissue. Option (D) suggests ischemia, which may be present in the infarcted area but may not be the primary gross finding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe crushing pain with radiation to the left arm suggests myocardial infarction. The autopsy of the heart would reveal normal heart tissue as this is a sudden cardiac event, not a chronic condition, and has not yet caused changes or scar tissue to develop. Therefore, the correct answer is (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question indicates that the patient died of a myocardial infarction, and the options refer to the gross examination of the heart. The correct answer is (B), which indicates that the heart tissue will be normal with no visible signs of infarction. Grossly visible changes occur only after several hours to days, and the options refer to those changes. Red granulation tissue, white patchy scar, and pallor of the infarcted tissue indicate healing that occurs after the infarction has occurred.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient experienced a myocardial infarction (MI) based on the symptoms and lab results, and the autopsy would show normal heart tissue because it was sudden and there was not enough time for tissue remodeling to occur. The other options describe changes in heart tissue after an MI, but they would not be present immediately after the event.
